comment_0:
This is about the fallacies and ignorance and narcissism of certain psychedelic enthusiasts. It's a masterfully humorous song, and full of truth.

The part where he says "Me, the chosen one. They chose me, and I didn't even graduate from fucking high school...."

It's a sort of slap in the face to all the psychonauts and self appointed mystics and shaman who walk around acting as if, or believing, that they have been granted special access to the mysteries of life. That they have tapped into some fount of knowledge about all the Big Questions that have eluded mankind since day one. Never mind the fact that many, more powerful, minds have been unable to give us definitive answers to these questions... they have been granted special access to the answers because...why? Because they took acid and believe in ufo's? 

No, because they are special, they have been chosen. It's a sort of narcissism, to think that you are so important that you get to know the mysteries of life that nobody else gets to know, and that you should simply be granted this knowledge and responsibility because you were wise enough to ingest a chemical that has been experimented with for most of the last century, by millions of people, some of them likely much more talented and intelligent than you.

The "Rosetta Stoned" feeling is a common occurance on lsd. I had it happen a few times when I used to take it as a teenager. You get this overwhelming feeling of having discovered some deeper, hidden meaning about life, a major revelation of some kind. But somehow, by the time you are sober again, the feeling is gone. Some faint echo of it nags at you, because it felt so real, what was it? Should have written it down...shit the bed...

Ok, so next time you take acid, and it happens again, but this time you are prepared, you brought your pen!
So you write down the essence of your revelation, this refinement of knowledge that has eluded mankind, but now you, the chosen one, can tell everyone, because you wrote it down! Good thinking!

You come down, and later feel that tug in your mind...what was it... oh yeah, the piece of paper! You pull it out of your pocket and read:

" A circle and a square are really the same thing!!!!"

" "Pink should be cherished and respected, it s here to mitigate aggression."

" If I try hard to honor you, you will try harder to honor me."

" The important number is 3!"

Huh?

Is this some gibberish, and some paraphasing of ancient and well know pieces of advice like the golden rule masquerading itself to you as something you invented on your own? What happened, it doesn't feel as overwhelming to read it sober, does it? 
Hell, none of these ideas are new, and all of them have been descibed and debated in much clearer and understandable language than this psychedelic obscuritan drivel anyhow...

comment_2:
This is what I get from it, it may not be what you get, and thatâs totally fine.  Keeping in mind the three languages on the Rosetta Stone and the above quotation.

There are three narratives that need to be deciphered in this song.  At the beginning we have the narrative of events told by the guy who is still suffering the effects of LSD to the doctors.  The garbled sound of the lyrics seems to accentuate the nonsensical lyrics themselves.  Then we get the second narrative, his inner thoughts.  This helps us understand the first narrative, he cant explain himself because he is still really stoned, but what he has to say does make some sense.  We are missing a third narrative, which is that of the aliens.  
So then what is the Rosetta Stone, his key to unlocking the cryptic message?  The title suggests itâs the LSD.  It is what allowed for the alien experience and makes the first nonsensical narrative possible, then the second more rational narrative.  The reason we are missing the alien narrative is because we have an unprepared individual with no frame of reference, he forgot his pen.  So he ends up missing the point.  You get what you can from the Rosetta Stone (LSD or the actual stone used to decrypt the hieroglyphs) but once you decrypt, you donât need the Rosetta Stone anymore.  Once you figure out how to read Hieroglyphs you donât need to translate through the stone again, you do it because you understand it.  Much like once you reach a bit of spiritual enlightenment you can âget there againâ because you understand it.  The story teller was not prepared and therefore did not have the frame of reference to understand the new perspectives he encountered.  It becomes a sort of response to âThird Eye.â

What makes this song cool to me is the humor used to poke fun at the stereotypical high school drop out that trips out just to trip out.  Tool makes some great stuff.

comment_9:
Heh, a lot of this song reminds me of the film Fear And Loathing in Las Vegas.

To expand on nonetospeakof's comments, here's an MJK quotation:

  "I think psychedelics play a major part in what we do, but having said that, I feel that if somebody's going to experiment with those things they really need to educate themselves about them. People just taking the chemicals and diving in without having any kind of preparation about what they're about to experience tend to have no frame of reference, so they're missing everything flying by and all these new perspectives. It's just a waste. They reach a little bit of spiritual enlightenment, but they end up going, 'Well, now I need that drug to get back there again.' The trick is to use the drugs once to get there, and maybe spend the next ten years trying to get back there without the drug."
 - Maynard James Keenan

I think this song is basically the artistic, musical version of that quote.  With "goddamn, shit the bed," he's saying he screwed up and he's trying to get back to where he was.  But perhaps he's trying to do it without the initial catalyst? (LSD, DMT, whatever)

I also think the vocals are very clever.  Being quite unconventional for MJK, they give the song a bit of a surreal sound (moreso than most Tool), especially with the delay voice, which is also slightly off-tune at times (obviously quite intentional).

comment_56: I believe this song is truly about a DMT experiance.  First, because of the lucid dreamlike experiances described in the lyrics.  Secondly, because of the alien visitation.  It is common for a DMT experiance to involve alien visits, in clinical studies about 20% of tests resulted in a trip with aliens.  Another reason is the fact that many people cannot handle the intensity of the onset hallucinations and do "shit the bed" though I believe Maynard is using that statement to describe failure.  Also, the user questioned whether he was alive or dead.  When I drank Ayahuasca, an Oral DMT mixture with an MAOI, I had vivid hallucinations, almost dreams, of my own death multiple times. Ahh TREXOR my old friend, getting yourself in quite a bit a trouble lately it seems!
I really must say that I don't think you should have opened your presents before Christmas morning! You ruined your own surprised and now your disappointed. I'm very sorry to have recently read all about it. Let me tell you a little story old buddy...

I waited! Damn it I waited till the very last second. I didn't cheat in any way. I wanted that first listen to be pure! I was at Best Buy when the doors opened on May 2nd, at 10am and I got my long awaited treasure. I was happy as a schoolgirl, playing with Great Gatsby looking cover and bubbling over with joy. Popped it in the CD player and headed for my sons play group. 
With the first listen I felt a bit like you have described, TREXOR. I felt like technically it was great and musically it was outstanding but lyrically it just seemed off. Not bad, not bad at all, I still loved it but I was feeling like Maynard's writing was lacking in something. Then it happened....
That night a good friend came over and in a few words changed the whole CD for me. He nonchalantly said, "I think this is his (MJK) most personal stuff to date." I was floored. How could he even think that, he must be out of his mind! But before we could delve too deep into the subject the conversation twisted and turned and went another way. 
The next morning at 8am I wanted so badly to wake his ass up and ask him how he could possibly say this was Maynardâs most personal work. It grinded on me all day... and so I listened and listened and listened and read and read and by the time we met again later that day I understood.
It is brilliant; it's wonderful, glorious. The difference... it's less cryptic, it's more straight foward. It is still Tool in every way but it gives you a feeling that after all of these years they have dropped some of the formality with us all. It's almost charming. 
Listen to every album they have made no two are alike, they are all Tool but they are also humans growing and changing and the music is a reflextion. Enjoy it for what it is TREXOR. It truly is an amazing collection of sounds!

comment_97:
Hmm, I think everyone took the interpretation of this song in the wrong direction. Instead it's become one big drug discussion. I don't even think that this song has anything to do with drugs. How hard is it to believe that the speaker is not on drugs and is simply recalling an alien encounter of the Fifth kind? 

Wikipedia's defination: A close encounter of the fifth kind involves direct communication between an extraterrestrial intelligence and a human being. This is the rarest and most controversial form of close encounter

Where on Lost Keys/Rosetta stoned does it indicate the use of hellucinogens? I don't do drugs but from the nurse's description of the speaker (No obvious signs of physcial trauma and Vital signs are stable), he seems fine to me.

My interpretation of the song also ties in with the idea that greater, otherworldy powers have been watching over human beings ever since the beginning and have played a major part in our growth and progression. The speaker gets abducted by extra-terrestrials and they give him information that can save the future of mankind from an impending danger. People who are abducted don't remember the experience and pass it off as merely a dream. Most of the time, people who claimed to have been abducted by aliens can actually recall the experience with the help of hypnosis. In some instances, people can remember it vividly on their own and it's usually a traumatic one, such as the speaker of the song.

Going back to the point, I don't see any evidence in Lost Keys/Rosetta stoned that the speaker is on an LSD trip. I mean seriously, think about it. Say the same thing happens to you and you go to the doctor and tell them that aliens abducted you, chose you to be the bearer (chosen one) on information that will save mankind. Do you think they'll believe you? No, cause it sounds ridiculous and they'll simply come to the conclusion that you've been doing drugs or on an LSD trip. Hence the title "Blame Hofmann".

Just to add one more thing, we all know what the Rosetta stone is right? I've read somewhere in one of the posts saying that that LSD is the Rosetta stone for "extra-terrestrial messages". IMO, the speaker IS the Rosetta stone but he sounds more like he's been doing drugs, hence the "Stoned" part.

Yes this song is about a guy's drug trip.  He said "A Deadhead. Chemistry". Deadhead as in The Greatful Dead, and they were notorious for their LSD use.  Also later in the song he says, "It was so real, Like I woke up in wonderland.... Will I ever be coming down".  
Plus look at the structure of the song itself.  Lipan Conjuring sounds tribal, perhaps a ceremony where he takes the drug.  Followed by Lost Keys which is all trippy, we are with this guy on his mental journey.  The end of Lost Keys is the doctor wanting to know what happened to him.  So the beginning of Rosetta Stoned this guy is all rambling, and talking super fast as he is still feeling the effects of the drug.  Then the middle part is all slow, and melodic and somewhat forelorn, as he is coming down.  Then the end is filled with anguish because he can't remember what happened in his trip as it was too intense.  This happens with a drug trip, it was so intense you forget a lot of what took place.  
So this song is blatantly obvious that it was about a drug trip.

comment_138:
well anti social... i've done acid dozens of times (probobly in the range of 30+ encounters of varying intensity) and DMT about half a dozen times...

i've smoked dmt in several of it's natural forms... i've smoked pure crystaline dmt... and i've drinken ayahuasca... 

and i won't even bother going into my  experience with mescaline, salvia, psilocybin mushrooms, amanita mushrooms... etc...

now, let me explain... if this song were to be about dmt it would have to be with ayahuasca because with smoking dmt, one would be coming down in a matter of 15 minutes after smoking ('will i EVER be coming down')... so if it's a dmt experience, it would have to be ayahuasca, being as ayahuasca last more like 3 or 4 hours... 

do hear even the most thickly veiled reference to ayahuasca in the course of this song? i don't... i hear several references to lsd though. not to mention that the first line in the song makes reference to the character eating a 'box of krispy kremes'... this would not even be possible on ayahuasca as it causes the most intense stomach cramps, vomiting, etc...

so, without any references to ayahuasca it seems silly to jump to the conclusion that dmt is being referenced in this song. 

especially when you consider that the effects of dmt and lsd are so similar that if one were to spend 5 minutes in the head of someone peaking on acid, and 5 minutes in the head of someone peaking on dmt, you would be virtually unable to distinguish the difference, even as an experienced tripper. 

they affect the same receptors and cause the same kinds of hallucinations... so saying that the song has 'more of a dmt feel' is just kind of a niave statement...

i'm not saying that this song is definately about drugs... cause it's vague enough to go either way... but there ARE drug references, and lsd IS the drug being referenced...

Just an idea:

The "Lost Keys" are piano keys (August Hoffman)

news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/…
A wealth of names and nationalities have been suggested to try to identify a man found wandering in Kent who communicates only through piano music. 
Health workers caring for the "Piano Man" could not confirm reports he had been identified as French street musician Steven Villa Masson. 

The National Missing Persons Helpline has had hundreds of calls and e-mails. 

Information has also been passed to West Kent NHS and Social Care Trust which is following up all leads. 

The mystery man was unable to communicate with police or carers after he was found in a street in Sheerness in a rain-soaked suit. 

Piano drawing 

When staff at the Medway Maritime Hospital gave him a pen and paper in the hope he would write his name, he drew a grand piano. 

His carers then put him in front of an instrument in the hospital chapel and he stunned them with a virtuoso classical performance. 

He has also composed music since he was found. 

Social worker Michael Camp said the man, who is in his 20s or 30s, is usually very anxious but "comes alive" when he plays. 

On Tuesday, a Polish street mime artist approached police in Rome saying he had worked with the man in Nice. 

Social workers are working through a list of at least 300 other names. 

The National Missing Persons Helpline has received more than 520 calls and more than 100 e-mails. 

Musical experts sought 

The trust has been approached by people from Australia, Canada, Sweden, Holland, Italy and France. 

"(He) continues to be cared for by the trust, and there has been no change in his condition," a spokesman said. 

The man has not said a word since police found him on 7 April. All the labels had been removed from every item of his clothing. 

The case has drawn comparisons with the 1996 film Shine which depicts the story of acclaimed pianist David Helfgott who suffered a nervous breakdown. 

Anyone who has information about The Piano Man is urged to call the helpline on 0500 700700. 

People calling from outside the UK can reach the Missing Persons Helpline on +44 20 8392 4545. People calling from the Irish Republic should dial 00 800 7000 7001.

1) The first (question) has to do with the Ouija session in which 'Obelisong' replies to you with an anagram...

Q) "Can you tell me something about the 'terrible' secret that one of the songs on the new record speaks of?"

A) "A OR ET TESTS ON D" (Rosetta Stoned)

That's all fine and dandy, as long as you have no problem believing that 'other-world' beings care to code their answers so cleverly... but...

This doesn't appear to coincide with a certain recent news entry in which you explained that the 'protagonist' in this particular song is none other than MAYNARD JAMES KEENAN.

2) The second issue is that you had stated in a past news entry that there would be NO guests on this album... but, if you read the credits for "Lipan Conjuring" you'll find Bill McConnell's name, not to mention the doctor and nurse in Lost Keys.

3) In the February newsletter you make a few references to Danny's ****, which I believe you later revealed represented his gong.. but what I don't understand is that in the same newsletter you write...

"After we fired a couple up, I asked if he'd managed to get a gong on the new one? "Yeah, on *****" he said with a mischievous smile."

So, why was 'GONG' so important to omit 3 times when you end up making direct reference anyway?

Hopefully you understand the confusion. Could you clear this up for us a bit?

A: If you read the post again you'll see that I never said that MJK was the so-called "protagonist." I said that he would be the one who knew the identity of the individual in question (as HE wrote the lyrics). For all I know, it isn't an actual person at all, or perhaps it's a composite of several people. Most likely, though, the lyrics and concept were inspired by a story told by Maynard's friend Bill Manspeaker (see the March, 2006 newsletter). Although the strange experience described by Bill happened to some people he knew who were camping at Giant Rock in Landers, California (and not at Area 51, as the lyrics state), this might just be a case of Maynard using a better know setting â that of Americaâs most famous secret base. I know from email that a lot of people think that I was the "protagonist" sitting out at Area 51 that night, but this is very doubtful for many reasons. First of all, as I've said, I have never eaten a Krispy Kreme doughnut. But more importantly, I've never taken LSD or DMT or any psychedelic drugs while out at Area 51. In my way of seeing things, it's just not the place for such things (for many reasons, some that should be quite obvious by now). However, in thinking about any possible inspiration on Maynardâs part, I did find one thing that MIGHT be of some relevance. In the May, 2005 newsletter, in talking about a recent trip to Area 51, I wrote the following with regards to Ray Santilli's controversial 'Magdalena' footage (more commonly known as the "Alien Autopsy): "With its combination of strange alien symbols, classical Greek, [proto] Phoenician and modern English, did anyone ever consider that what 'crashed' was a Rosetta Stone of sorts?

All things considered, we might never know the true identity of 'Dave', but with all those Krispy Kreme doughnuts we sure as hell can't rule out Eric Cartman, even though he hates hippies. Incidentally, last Saturday I made my 51st trip to Area 51 (mainly just to cure the deficiency of Venus.) Unfortunately there was no activity to report on the moonless night other than the usual thing of being carefully watched by security personnel at the perimeter. Well, at least I donât remember anything unusual happening.

comment_175:
Alrighty then...
So far I agree with everyone, even those who are arguing with one another. It's the fact that so many different interpretations can be made from the one song/album that makes Tool & their work so freakin sweet! Anyway here's my interpretation:
  So far the big debate is whether or not Dave (the guy in the song) is tripping balls or really did contact 'extra dimensional beings' but there is a third possibility i.e. he's gone insane. There's no doubt that Dave has had waaaaaaaay too much acid, a box of Krispy Kreme's worth if I'm not mistaken. The obliviousness of his situation i.e. not realising he's eaten acid laced donuts (a whole box worth OMGWTFBBQ!!112) explains why he doen't realise he's tripping and makes the trip even more mentally damaging.
  Anyway back to my point, (if I ever had one) the section where E.T tells Dave that he is the 'Chosen One' who will deliver 'The Message' undoubtedly stands out in the track but there's more to this part than just aliens & drugs. When you consider the Messianic delusions that are common with Schizophrenia and the fine line between religion and madness in general, it seems that Dave's seemingly spiritual epxerience could be the result of him developing a full blown psychosis.
  It is well known that some people who take enough acid can trip out so much that they don't come back to reality ever. Detatchement from reality is essentially what psychosis is so Dave has definately done some permanent damage to his noggin, even if he ever comes down.
  Another interesting theory is that the song seems to have three distinct themes: Aliens/EDBs, hallucanigens and psychosis. This could correlate with the three scripts of the Rosetta Stone !WOW!
  As for the LSD/DMT debate; Dave is on acid (among other things maybe) but if you add up the length of "Lipan Conjuring", "Lost Keys" and "Rosetta Stoned" it amounts to approximately 15 minutes. Hmm... Keep in mind that if you do listen to these tracks on DMT I won't be held responsible :P
  Finally, shitting the bed seems to have more significance than just failure. They say that the last thing you do before you die is shit yourself (if you're packing that is.) The final part of the song conveys the feeling of shitting one's self (It did to me... ahem...) Anyway it's possible that Dave dies at the end of the song thus shitting himself at the last moment- end of song. This ties in to the the theme of death that the whole album conveys.

  Don't forget your pen.

This track begins with "Alrighty then", which was a repeated line in the Ace Ventura movies. This makes me believe this song might be a comment on Jim Carrey as an actor, or on his career in general. Jim is a noted fan of heavy/death metal.

Many Tool songs are thought to carry comments on religion, and Jim played the main character in Bruce Almighty. This song is about enlightenment.  The spikes that happen in your life and how you deal with it.

We are sitting and wasting ourselves away in this "bed" of our life with so many of the answers.  But we've learned to let ourselves be knocked down and we take those answers to our grave.

This guy had an experience with aliens telling him he's the ONE, and I think when it says "I forgot my pen" I think that is a metaphor.

It is becoming a more popular belieft that this life is like a dream, and we all carry the pens to write in the experiences.  This guy went through this experience that gave him such clarity in mind, yet when he left, he denied himself so many times that he was back to that cloudy state.

And then when I see him in the bed shitting himself, I picture that is him in the future.  That he has done nothing with the information he has recieved, and therefore is left old, withered, and ironically a waste in his own waste.

comment_267:
A common belief of casual acid trippers is that Albert Hoffman, father of present day LSD, created the supplement to self-examination in order to achieve spiritual enlightment. This concept is utterly invalid. In fact, utilitizing drugs as a so called spiritual shortcut, has an adverse effect on spiritual development. These chemicals are a deterent, not a catalyst. Addiction and dependence are two very big steps backwards in the advancement of ones spiritual maturation, evolution, and development. Theres no way around the fact that the path to enlightenment requires meditation in order to climb to a higher level of self-awareness, coupled with the process of self-acceptance. The concept that drug experiences can lead to the uncovering of the singular answer to life is a fallacy. The concept is fundamentally unsound at its most basic level, simply because there is NO singular question being proposed here in our reality.

Enlightenment is ethereal, and the path towards it is tedious and at times exasperating. The fact of the matter is that the application of self-discovery through deep self-examination, meditation, and internal reflection can never be supplemented by a simple chemical. The human consciousness is far to complex and magnificant. True enlightenment and awakening is more satisfy, I imagine, then the effects of a drug trip.

Bearing this in mind, we can begin to investigate the peice "Lost Keys/Rosetta Stoned" by Tool.

The protaganist depicted here, who is clearly recalling a vivid acid trip, honestly believes that he himself was given the ultimate premonition...the end of humanity, by alien beings none the else. And Keenan, truly gifted as an awesome lyricist, adds insult to fallacy it seems, portraying the protaganist as having forgotten his pen at time of the alien visitation.

The "chosen one" here in "Lost Keys/ Rosetta Stoned" represents an entire generation of intellectual drug abusers under the misconception that chemicals can supplement real spiritual discipline. Ultimately, the "stoned" individual is a failure, dropping out of high school to pursue a life of drug abuse. And more saddening is the fact that he is ignorant to his own failure.

Keenan drives this point home with the line, "goddamn, shit the bed"...a failure, a 'typical' failure.

Very brilliant song. Sets the scene perfectly, but more importantly, stresses the need for individuals to become better aware that drug abuse is not the supplement for sober spiritual discovery.

I can go on to say how this song is the antithesis to Third Eye but not here or now.

comment_279:
I agree with most interpretations of this song that give it more credit than a simple description of an acid trip or the effects of DMT on the brain or whatever. Even though 10,000 Days is a much more "personal" Tool album relatively speaking, Tool's lyrics are social satire (to put it mildly) more often than not.

Especially considering the fact that there are other analogies on the album drawn between psychoactive drugs' bodily effects and society ("The Pot"), the title of this song says a lot about its meaning, I think.  The Rosetta Stone was, as many posters have pointed out, a translation device that archaeologists and historians used to translate between ancient greek, latin, and hieroglyphics: a huge breakthough at the time. The fact that the song's speaker is "Rosetta Stoned" suggests that there is some huge breakthrough that needs to be communicated to the world, something that would synthesize a bunch of disparate understandings, but due to the way we have "drugged" ourselves in this modern world, we can't get the message across.

comment_281: well what somebody said about how DMT can be naturally produced in the brain is, i believe, in fact, true.  in fact, some researchers now believe that many of what people describe as encounters with extra terrestrials are in fact releases of DMT in the brain induced by some ordinary means.  driving on a country road at night induces a trancelike state believed likely to cause this, which is why a lot of people have these experiences in such circumstances.  I would say that the term "Yogi DMT" probably refers to a release of DMT via transcendental meditation.  Interestingly, the gland in the brain believed to secrete DMT is the Pineal gland.  the Pineal gland is biologically similar to our eyes in some respects, and is a key element of the seratonergic system of the human brain.  In some fish, the pineal gland is actually developed into a sensory organ very similar to a crude eye.   this is generally the scientific explanation for what many, including tool, might call the Third Eye.  Basically, "prying open" one's third eye (a la that song off Aenima) would be thus interpreted to be a DMT experience, while to many eastern philosophies this experience is NOT thought to be drug-induced but a natural part of existence.  Thus, the idea of this alien coming down as god to reveal one's nature as the chosen one is not entirely as ridiculous as many here seem to think, nor is it as elementary as a simple drug problem.

comment_283: One plausible and scientifically tested theory is that alien encounters (1st and 3rd kinds) are actually intense hallucinations induced in 'sensitive' people by fluxuations in magnetic fields. I watched this experiment where a bunch of scientists had several mentally stable test subjects wear this helmet that generates low level magnetic fields and locked them in a dark room in total isolation. The scientists, in a separate control room, then caused different fluxuations in the magnetic fields generated by the helmet. After this,the test subjects recalled experiencing hallucinations ranging from bright glowing lights to sensing prescences in the room with them, when they were certain they were alone in there. The thing is, we always here about the accounts of grey skinned, bug eyed aliens who probe people, however we rarely hear about the accounts of carpeted UFOs with a dog piloting the craft inside a kennel. I'm not saying aliens don't exist but I am saying that not all encounters are genuine. Unfortinately any genuine encounters are lost in the mythology.

First of all, Tool's lyrics are ''up for interpretation'' but I'll point out some of the things that stick out from my experience. I do not claim to have a synthesis of this piece, only a collection of mostly strong opinions and theories. I welcome you to disprove anything and hope you do. *personal note that you can call ''an effort to support claims'' or you can chose to not be paranoid or out of being lazy skip over - SOMEONE WHO IS defInetly not me listened to this song on their come down of an ayahuasca trip during their 7th hour and it seemed to be a good illustration of how slow time was going for SOMEONE WHO IS defInetly not me .

Things that are apparent to me:
1.From the begining of the song to the end of the song there is the sence of 'coming down. Anyone who has had a time distorted experience can verify this. The fast talk/explanation in the begining is an overload of information and yet it's not studdered except for the obscure lyrics in the ''badadabadg bug eyes'' (which by the way reminds me of Finnegans Wake:First page, perenthetical and coinciding with ''The fall'') Anyway, Robert Anton Wilson (among Leary and others but I can't give reference to them) seems to be the proponent or supported of the idea of a Neurological Reality Tunnel, this is what you percieve. ''The nervous system receives over a billion signals every minute and the brain can't sort it out so it chooses some based on imprints and subconscious defences'' Not to ramble on too long he also believes among other 'mystics' that psychadelics can widen the tunnel of information that you brain can process. It makes sence to exclude any interpretation of a 'religious experience' or something about making fun of Ron L. or anyone else.  Further more he slows down during the whole song which is signal of his Reality Tunnel going back to normal or him ''coming down.'' I think this point has been pushed enough so on to...

2. The similarities in tone and dynamics in the ''Then he looked right through me'' part and lipan conjuring. This is just a hunch but it makes sence because psychadelics (ESPECIALLY ayahuasca and mushrooms) are thought to be able to be very sound sensitive. What does that mean? Well simply it means you're very aware and can put your finger on a lot more of the gradients of glossalalia. Terence Mckenna talks about this in True Hallucinations in a more defined way. If you're having a skepticle time with this try mentally humming lipan conjuring and hum the 'waltzy' part of Rosetta; also take into account that he is still ''coming down'' and that you'll need to slow down to make a just comparison.

3.This one is easier to tell in Live versions of the songs and this one is probably my favorite because trying to grab any meaning seems impossible sober. Ok, if you have seen a live version you know that his fast talk in the begining is complimented with a megaphone. I tried to catagorize content with when he is (not really but it's easy to understand) ''rambling'' and when he is using that beautiful voice of his. Something stuck out right away. When he talks in the megaphone almost everything he says is culturally defined and is punned. It's very rich in connatation. To my mind it's the Finnegans Wake of our generation. 

When he isn't talking out of the megaphone there are two implications I got thus far (and let me be first to get this completely wrong). One is that he seems to be washed of his ego-the cultural stronghold on his language (we all know what that means)- and he sounds like he's lost or just trying to do something nice for the world.  The second would be that when he's talking through the megaphone he is talking a changing his language for other people (rough interpretation of it) and when he isn't it's more to himself.

''Don't even know what that means, must remember to write it down.'' This line is really the rosetta stone to me in this whole topic. ''Don't even know what that means'' has the tone and content that is pure, something that seems to me as egoless as he gets. And then what does he say? ''Must remember to write it down.'' The tone slopes down to the begining of the riff from a place of purity to the same person in for personal gain. 

Last thoughts:
A beautiful song. Really this is my favorite song from Tool.  I would like to go back and for those who have tampered with Finnegans Wake keep in my what's said. I feel sympathy for him (and us dispite my lack of disposition) and his failure. And yet his failure is so common. firstly, Dr. Hoffman in the song previous to this is the father of LSD, so its a LSD trip, not a DMT trip (since DMT trips only last about 10mins). Various lyrics link it to this such as "Will I ever be coming down" and "fuck me! It's gotta be the dead head chemistry." 

The title is a play on the Rosetta Stone, which was a large stone discovered in 1800. this stone, created in about 800BC is one of the only known pieces of script that has both Egyptian Heiroglyophics and Ancient Greek, and therefore is a crucial link in history between the two great civilisations. My opinion on this is that through this LSD trip, the protagonist has managed to communicate with another civilisation (aliens). If you've ever been on acid, you'll love the way this song is written and the music that goes with it.

I think this song has a huge religous undertone, let me explain. The song is about an ET that gives a stoned man the "details to our ending" and a "message of hope for those who choose to hear it, and a warning for those who do not..."

comment_342:
Imagine this, if you will :

You've just tripped your balls off from a chemical cocktail of heroic proportion and had a revelation of the deepest kind.  You understood who you are, where you actually were, and the walls of concrete reality fell around you to expose the true undercurrent of the universe where there was an intelligent being waiting for you with open arms to tell you the secrets of life, love, and the universe.  It all made so much sense...

It also scared you so much you pissed your pants.  Quite literally.  You felt so self-concious, pissing your pants in front of this greater intelligence - please, please, hope and pray that it doesn't notice or is polite enough at least to ignore it and continue to reveal the mysteries...

Luckily, it did.  However, it took you by surprise by telling you that it was your job to communicate these ideas to the world in order to bring about a shift in global consciousness.  You were the chosen one - yes, you.  You didn't even graduate fuckin' high school.  And all of this was as real as the 1's and 0's that are making up the letters your reading right now - as clear as the translucent skin of the waking world.  It all made so much sense...

But you couldn't write it down, because you didn't bring your goddamn pen with you.  So fucking typical.

Then you shit the bed.  Again, quite literally.

You eventually become aware that you are in a hospital because you were freaking out so badly that someone must've dropped you off.  You also must've been scaring the hell out of the staff, because they've strapped you down to your bed.  Your feet are cold as you try to hold on the fragments of what you've just experienced and make some sense of them.  It used to make so much sense...

But you still don't have your goddamn pen.  And you shit the bed, again.

comment_386: I just breezed in through here tonight looking for the latest gossip about this song.  It seems like alot of the same old nonsense I'm hearing here.  It sounds like more of an attempt to assert the self up in here than it sounds like true discussion.  Here are some notions I have about Rosetta Stoned.  First off the first page I went to was page number eleven so much of my reaction will be taylored to what I heard there.  One of the reasons I clicked on eleven was because the chorus for rosetta stoned is in eleven groups of quarter notes (with a few manditory sextuplets for filler, etc) played as alternating six feel with a five feel.  When it comes to the elevens in the length of this song as well as Lipan Conjuring that could be a reference to the meter of rosetta stoned or more probably either a coincidence or a binary code that can't mean much (not that they could anyway)... and endless string of ones is not much differerent from the same in zeros -- without context.  As far as my interpretation of this song I think that this is Tool's experimentation into the 'lost keys' of rhythm.  Lipan Conjuring is about a minute long (close enough for humans) and a minute is sixty seconds.  The bridge (if you can call it that, there are no lyrics during the long section I'm thinking of) is sixty beats per repetition.  Danny plays the snare on every third beat and then starts over while he plays every five sixteenth notes on the kick while carrying steady tom beat. Also in this section if you count the reps starting with the one where Adam comes in with his guitar you get seven reps (plus the two prior) I'd like to believe that this is just to try to drive the point home about missing numbers.  Basically what I'm saying with this post is that this song is a panorama of metrical 'keys' and if there is a message it's just that it's just a bunch of sound over time - no message.  Words are just sound is what it amounts to ("don't know, won't know).  Has anybody tried listening to the songs in the order of their meters?  Try this:  Intention (7), The Pot(8), Jambi(9), Vicarious(10), Right In Two(11), Wings (12) Rosetta Stoned(13) - this last one needs some explanation: Right after the break in the music towards the end, when it starts up again I believe Adam is playing in thirteen (lots of repeat notes and and stuff but I think that the overall rep is thirteen) and it explains why it's so confusing especially because Danny is once again playing his sixty count over it with maynard vocalizing on the fives with the kick drum. comment_387:
Alrighty then..

I noticed a few connections to Aemina in this song.
  At 6:00 Rosetta Stoned time there is a theme that sounds like a recurrent theme from H.  Also - 40 seceonds into H there is a theme that sounds like the theme at 2:00 in RS (this one is subtle).
 At 2:55 in Third Eye the driving guitar riff for much of the song comes in which sounds suspeciously like the riff that drives the chorus of Rosetta Stoned which makes its appearance at 2:58.

I was smoked up one day and I listened to Rosetta Stoned and I was just thinking about what it reminded me of and then I heard the lyric "Can't remember what they said" and I found it humerous that I was trying to remember how the part went and when I was listening to third eye one day in my room I almost shit the bed when I finally connected the two guitar parts together.  I got another kick a few moments ago when I noticed that they both kick in at the same time in the song while I was looking up the time index.  It's almost like "I do not recognize the vessel but the eyes seem so familiar" is reflected in the perspective of the witness/victim in RS, although it's a stretch - I don't think that "sominferous almond eyes" are the same as eyes like "phosphorescent desert buttons".

Personal opinion time.
I think you can blame Hoffman and other drug pioneers for the fact that mystical experiences that are given credibility seem scarce these days.  I wasn't around before there were so many drugs widely available and in common knowledge but I'll bet that if a person came to you and started telling a typical stoner story while they were totally distraught you'd have had more reason to believe them than you would now.  Think about the time of people that trip hard on drugs and why.  I'm not so much referring to stimulants like cocaine, tobacco, etc.. but DMT, Psilocybin, LSD.  The hals take a different type of appreciation than just a good physical feeling.  Many of the hardcore trippers are probably the same people that would've fasted for days on end back in the day to elicit a certain awareness.  Most of the people I'm talking about don't have families to worry about, maybe they aren't good with people.  Maybe they are very close to a sacred piece of knowledge but they just can't quite get it without going through some drastic measures.  People used to listen to dreams more often and people also paid more attention to stories people told.  Sometimes it isn't even important that the story be true (by conventional standards) it could still carry a message.
On the bright side.  Perhaps most of the stories you heard about divine revelation and all that from back in the day were merely the ravings of people who needed good drugs for their psychosis (or whatever the current medical term is for somebody who's sober but out of his mind) or maybe just good advice from somebody telling them that they picked the wrong mushrooms to go in the soup.
I also think that this song is sort of a gift to the fans.  Especially all the fans that tripped so hard over their albums and at their shows.  For classic tool material comparable to third eye and other trippy tunes this one has it all.  It's almost as if the fans themselves wrote some of it.  That's just to say that I don't think this song carries any message personal to Maynard (even if he's 'been there').  It's a wonderful piece of music especially for fans of rhythm and unusual narrative styles.  It's also a good song to listen to if you've never tripped but want to hear something typical for that kind of experience.

PS:  I listened to this song last halloween on my first acid trip and it was... absolutely sublime, funny, groovy (I was freaking out in my bed to the grooves - I couldn't stop moving, it was too awesome) and it sounds sooooo smooth, especially the way the effects are layered to obscure which intrument is creating the sound, like that part early on where something is saying to the patient "shit the bed" maybe it's just his body telling him what's about to happen but then he cries out "You better listen!" and drowns it out.  No wonder he shit the bed - he wouldn't listen.  That just further supports my belief that the lyrics as a societal issue aren't the key here.  All this even though I had already been totally familiar with the song before that trip.  So listen to it sober or stoned but you better listen.

comment_394:
Yes, I think a heavy dose of humor, ridiculing every misinformed burned out druggie who thinks they know the answer to the worlds problems after they trip.

Also, more seriously, a look at the consequences of using psychedelics incorrectly, or with the wrong intentions. Maynard, of all people, knows how powerful these drugs can be, and has stated in interviews that ideally, after one receives a genuine "religious" or "spiritual" experience with a psychedelic, he should then work at achieving such a state without the use of drugs. 

So overall, both a laugh at confused burnouts and a warning that, while psychedelics can provide intense, positive, life changing experiences, they can have severe consequences when abused.

comment_432:
This song, along with "Lost Keys (Blame Hoffman)" is about the dark side of LSD.  Hoffman is the last name of the doctor (not in the song) who, quite literally, discovered the chemical LSD by being subjected to it by mistake, hence "Blame Hoffman" for losing your keys...which is probably some sort of variant of "Losing your marbles".  In "Lost Keys" when the doctor asks the patient what happened, it turns into Rosetta Stoned

This song is obviously about the person who's high on LSD, his confusion.  Because LSD can be one of the most harmful drugs, mentally.  Otherwise explaining how Maynard speaks so quickly and is speaking of stupid things, conspiracy theories with Area 51 and other things of those sorts.

While generally LSD was a sort of spiritual escape for some people, others weren't so fortunate and were scarred for life.  Rosetta Stoned is obviously an assumption of people's view points that suffered from negative LSD effects.

Summary of my interpretation: A middle-class teenage girl (who watches too much television) wants to find a deeper meaning to her life, and explore the complexities of the world. To do this, she goes to a club/rave/party where she knows there will be drugs, thinking that drug-use and the counterculture are a means of finding the meaning of life.
In reality, she was drugged with multiple psychedelics (and later sedatives) by a man at the party. She was then raped by the man.
She however, thought she was being abducted by space aliens. Her whole experience is told as if it were a telivsion show/movie. She becomes psychotic after the incident, and is put in a mental hospital while she is under the belief that she is the chosen one.

Moral: Television has misled most of us into believing a false reality. A lot of people are under the belief that using drugs will lead to creativity, when really the naïve use of drugs could end up getting a person raped or make a person psychotic. Modern cultureâs perception has been so distorted by media that all communication is deteriorating.

I will offer my deciphering of the Rosetta Stoned (even though Tool has said their fans should focus less on the lyrics and more on the music):

"10 to 2 am, X, yogi DMT, and a box of krispy kreme's in my "need to know" pose just outside of area 51"

The narrator went to a club/party hence "10-2am". The narrator did multiple drugs at the club/party. Then the narrator went outside the club/party, hence the "just outside of Area 51". His/her "need to know pose" is his way of saying that he was thinking deeply and philosophically, or trying to pose like he/she was an intellectual.

There are a few different ways to interpret the use of the term "Area 51"
1. He/she considers everyone at the club/party to be different than him, like an alien.
2. He/she thinks that the club/party is where abnormal people ("aliens") are kept in hiding from society.
3. "Area 51" is where he/she is heading to. A place where the unknown and large-scale secrets are located. He/she is pursuing the meaning of life.

"contemplating the whole chosen people thingy "
Simple enough. He is thinking deeply about "chosen people" and saviors. A different interpretation (which I wouldn't support as much) is that he is referring to the nation of Israel "God's chosen people", which is stuck in a heated conflict of religion which biblically indicates the apocalypse.

"when just then a flaming stealth banana split the sky like one would hope but never really expect to see in a place like this. Cutting right angle donuts on a dime and stopping right at my birkinstocks, and me yelping 'holy fucking shit!'"

1. The drugs are kicking in. He wasn't expecting it to be this powerful.
2. He finds a drug dealer who has high-grade psychedelics (LSD)
3. A Nuclear weapon just went off "flaming stealth banana split the sky". People hoped that a nuclear weapon would have been detonated in another nation, but they weren't expecting one to go off in their own nation. The explosion got very close to him "stopping right at my birkenstocks", or maybe he actually did die and is unaware of it. The words "holy fucking shit" might be significant. "Holy" could be referring to religion, and how it is going to "fuck us over".

âwith Isabella Rossellini lips, and breath that reeked of vanilla chig champa,â

Possibly, the drug dealer had just gotten out of a yellow volkswagon bus (âbanana vesselâ) which are known for being drove by hippies.


âand hovered above my bug eyes, my gaping jaw, and my sweaty L. Ron Hubbard upper lip and all I could think was, âI hope uncle martin here doesn't notice that I pissed my fuckin pants!!ââ

He is perplexed and awed by the drug dealer. This part makes me begin to think the narrator is a âregular joe working manâ, and he is seeing the drug-culture for the first time. Perhaps the narrator only knows what he sees on TV, this would explain the constant movie/television references.

âso light in his way, like an apparition, that he had me crying out...
"fuck me! It's gotta be the dead head chemistry. (the) blotter got right on top o' me. Got me seeing E mutha fuckin T!â

The acid and/or other drugs that he took is making him freak out. Now he sees someone who he refers to as ET. Now, ET is automatically and humorously assumed to be the alien from the movie ET. But what could ET stand for? Of course, extra-terrestrial is a given, but I think it stands for EnterTainment. Or, television. comment_458:
What I think:

Maynard always has the lyrics of songs tie together in their albums.  And the last three songs (excluding triad) Rosetta Stoned, Intension, Right in Two, seems to be a critique of humanity to me.  So I tend to believe this is more based on humanity's shortcommings rather than drug abuse (drug abuse could be considered one I suppose but this is more important than just that).  

Rosetta Stone is a program to help people learn new languages so I think this character in this song got 'stoned' from hearing a new 'language' which in this case was the aliens' form of communication.  And by stoned I don't mean good times and laughter I mean his mind got completely thrown in the gutter and he can no longer think straight because of what he was shown.  Because the alien form of communicating is completely beyond the capabilities of a human mind and he was reduced to a babaling idiot and is now therefore in a hospital.  Pleading with people "You believe me, don't you? 
Please believe what I just said".  And not comprehending people "And can anyone tell me why 
Y'all sound like Peanuts parents?"

If I remember correctly the tone and pace of the lyrics changes from before the lyrics "You'd better. You'd better. You'd better. You'd better listen" where it was fast paced and detailed, and then those lyrics came, whether they are the characters words or the aliens, and then after that the message is delivered ("Then he looked right through me"), all sane thoughts are lost to the wind and for the most part the speech is slower (easier to understand anyway) where the persons mind is not as detailed as it used to be and more aloof.  

I think his reference to "But I forgot my pen" was the characters last sane thought before he was shown, whatever it was he was shown.  Thinking to himself almost jokingly, 'i need to record this but i dont have my pen...*blam*'

So from here I venture from things which are shown in the lyrics to what I believe is the purpose of the song.  Like I said earlier, near the end of the album it becomes more evident of describing the faults of humanity, and i think this song is just to show how pathetic our minds really are.  For instance, compare our minds to an ant.  Each indivual ant has a job or purpose, and ways of going about that purpose, they also have problems which impede them and rewards from achieving goals (the prosperity of the hive).  Now compare the ants lives to us, we (humans) are probably unknown objects to them, natural phenomena* if you will.  If an ant was shown one shred of our consicousness I believe that ant's mind would probably be overwhelmed.  Even if we were just trying to warn it of a flood coming and what would be the "The details of [their] ending."  So, for the sake of argument put ourselves in the position of the ants and the humans are the aliens.  I now believe you can see where I am coming from where the person would be "Overwhelmed as one would be, placed in [his] position", brain dead and unable to keep control of his simple bodily funtions (taking a shit when he is supposed to).

So for all of our overwhelming and vital problems we are really not that important.  Quite pathetic actually.  And as a side note I think it can be derived that, the thought that we even think we understand the smallest bit of a higher intelligence's intention or reason, whether it be a god or an alien species, is purly arrogant.

I kinda think I am biased with this since I am big into sci-fi so my imagination can wander in this direction but I don't see that as a bad thing.



So I think you guys can understand where I am coming from with all of this, I understand that the vocals for Tool always have multiple levels and different ways of looking at it, which is one thing that makes their music art instead of just the pointles babling we here most of the time today.  So I think there is no 'right' interpretation to the song, only your interpretation.

is actually "I hope uncle Quark here doesn't notice that I pissed my fuckin pants!!"  But this is neither here nor there, i guess.

comment_482:
Perhaps Im way off on this, but I dont care.

I was high on morphine, in my isolation room depp in the cancer ward, listening to my newly aquired collection of 10 000 days mp3s.  I woke up sweating sometime in the middle of the night, and this song brought me out of my haze only to scare the crap out of me...and the meaning to this song has always seemed clear.  Maybe my perspective alters this drastically, but his hospital references ..birkinstocks and donuts are the usual long term visitor garb.  Orange slices are pretty much the only thing anyone will ever eat off those hospital tray meals... 

Considering he wrote so many songs about his dying mother, to throw this one into that pile only makes sense.

To me, this song is about the last days he spent with his mother before she died.
Area 51, being the hospital ..and the alien being the mother he hardly recognizes.
The drug references, more a plea for a greater understanding of life/death/purpose and all that.
I think he sees it as his mission to record his experiences and thoughts and retell them, and to make a difference somehow by helping other through their crap ...

At the end of the song, he is putting himself in her shoes, and imagining the time when he will be on his own death bed ...

comment_488:
This song is yet another example of how badly Maynard dislikes L Ron Hubbard and Scientology. It even says in the lyrics "...my sweaty L Ron Hubbard upper lip...".
Hubbard came up with Dianetics, which was basically a 'selfhelp' program, and it eventually evolved into the religion known as scientology. L ROn Hubbard believed that he was the one who had been selected to tell humanity the 'truth' about our origins and our ultimate ending, and the basis of the beliefs of scientology are that humans are, in a nutshell, the reincarnated souls of aliens that were killed millions of years ago. WHere this fits in with the song is, first off, the UFO references, the 'stealth bananna', area 51, etc. The person in the song was visited by an 'x-files being' and revealed to that he is the chosen one to deliver the message to humanity (as l ron hubbard believed he was chosen) and all the references to being high are maynards way of saying that there's NO way hubbard came up with all of this and seriously believes it, unless of course, he was high. THe intro, blame hoffman, can be a reference that the guy who came up with LSD is to blame for all this scientology BS because his chemical enabled hubbard to mislead so many people. ANd i know this is a horribly sloppy comment, but i was ina hurry xp
